value: aava_1.0_score
description

The two metadata versions represent the same conceptual workflow model with significant structural reorganization and moderate schema evolution. AAVA 2.0 introduces hierarchical improvements but removes some metadata completeness.

Core workflow semantics preserved: DI_DataSpecs_Modelupdates_SN workflow maintains same three-agent pipeline (Technical Specification -> Delta Model Changes -> Functional Test Cases) with identical business logic and processing flow.

Major structural reorganization: AAVA 1.0 uses flat 'nodes' array vs AAVA 2.0's nested 'workFlowDetail' + 'workflowAgents' hierarchy. This represents architectural evolution toward better separation of concerns.
Workflow identifier: 'workflowId' (1594) renamed to nested 'workFlowDetail.id' (2147). Semantic meaning preserved but structural access pattern changed.
Workflow name: 'workflowName' moved from root to 'workFlowDetail.name' with minor formatting change ('DI_DataSpecs_Modelupdates_SN' vs 'DI DataSpecs Modelupdates SN').
Agent container: 'nodes' array renamed to 'workflowAgents' array. Semantic meaning identical but improved naming convention.
Agent naming: 'agentName' renamed to 'name' within agent objects. Simplified but semantically equivalent.
Model reference: 'model' field renamed to 'modelDeploymentName' with version upgrade ('gpt-4' -> 'gpt-4.1'). Enhanced specificity and versioning.
Tool references: 'tools' array replaced with 'toolReferences' array. AAVA 2.0 shows empty arrays vs AAVA 1.0's populated tool references.
Task structure removal: AAVA 2.0 removes nested 'task' objects containing 'description' and 'expectedOutput'. This represents significant metadata loss affecting governance and traceability.
Agent identification: AAVA 2.0 introduces explicit 'agentId' fields (3885, 3474, 3545) providing unique identifiers absent in AAVA 1.0.
Metadata completeness degradation: AAVA 2.0 loses detailed task specifications, expected outputs, and cost estimation sections present in AAVA 1.0, reducing operational transparency.
ID evolution: Workflow ID changed from integer 1594 to 2147, and agent-level IDs introduced. Suggests system evolution and enhanced entity management.

Tool integration: AAVA 1.0 explicitly references 'DI_Github_File_Writer_Z' tool, while AAVA 2.0 shows empty 'toolReferences' arrays, potentially indicating tool abstraction or configuration externalization.
AAVA 1.0 JSON syntax validation: Valid JSON structure with consistent typing, proper nesting, and no orphaned references. All string fields properly quoted and arrays well-formed.
AAVA 2.0 JSON syntax validation: Valid JSON structure with consistent typing and proper nesting. Minor inconsistency in 'workFlowDetail' camelCase vs 'workflowAgents' lowercase 'w'.

Version evolution assessment: AAVA 2.0 represents a major structural refactoring (v1->v2) with improved hierarchy but reduced metadata richness. Migration complexity: Medium due to structural changes.
Backward compatibility risk: Structural changes in workflow and agent object models may break existing parsers, ETL processes, and governance tools expecting AAVA 1.0 schema.
Metadata governance risk: Loss of task-level metadata in AAVA 2.0 reduces audit trail, cost tracking, and operational visibility compared to AAVA 1.0's comprehensive task specifications.
Tool reference ambiguity: AAVA 2.0's empty 'toolReferences' arrays create uncertainty about actual tool dependencies and integration patterns.

Agent semantic preservation: All three agents (DI_Data_Technical_Specification_SN, DI_Delta_Model_Changes_SN, DI_Functional_Test_Cases_SN) maintain identical core descriptions and functional purposes across versions.
Model versioning: Consistent upgrade from 'gpt-4' to 'gpt-4.1' across all agents suggests coordinated platform evolution and improved model capabilities.
